verses.text: Once again Jesus began to teach beside the sea. A very large crowd gathered around Him, so He got into a boat and sat in it on the sea, while all the crowd stayed on the shore.
verses.comment: The image of Jesus teaching from a boat demonstrates His authority over creation and the practical needs of large crowds. The use of creation motifs (sea, land) foreshadows His mastery over the elements.

verses.text: He taught them many things in parables, and in His teaching He said to them:
verses.comment: Jesus' use of parables fulfills prophecy (see Ps. 78:2) and indicates divine wisdom in revealing spiritual truths gradually. The teaching method requires an authoritative interpreter.

verses.text: "Listen! Behold, a sower went out to sow."
verses.comment: The sower represents Christ or anyone spreading God's word. 'Listen!' signals the importance of the message. The motif recalls Isaiah 55:10-11—the Word never returns void.

verses.text: And as he sowed, some seed fell along the path, and the birds came and devoured it.
verses.comment: The path depicts hardened hearts; birds often symbolize evil or demonic forces opposing the Word. The parable foreshadows spiritual warfare.

verses.text: Other seed fell on rocky ground, where it did not have much soil, and immediately it sprang up, because it had no depth of soil.
verses.comment: Rocky ground indicates shallow receptivity—an emotional response without deep roots. True discipleship requires deeper formation.

verses.text: When the sun rose, it was scorched, and because it had no root, it withered away.
verses.comment: Trials and persecution ('the sun') test the depth of one's faith. Genuine perseverance is seen in those firmly rooted.

verses.text: Other seed fell among thorns, and the thorns grew up and choked it, and it yielded no grain.
verses.comment: Thorns signify worldly concerns and distractions. The need for spiritual disciplines to prevent choking by worldly cares is implied.

verses.text: Other seeds fell into good soil and produced grain, growing up and increasing and yielding thirty, sixty, and a hundredfold.
verses.comment: The abundant fruit points to God's superabundant grace working through those properly disposed to receive His Word.

verses.text: And He said, "He who has ears to hear, let him hear."
verses.comment: A call to attentive, obedient listening. Echoes Old Testament prophetic calls for response and the need for spiritual discernment.

verses.text: When He was alone, those around Him with the twelve asked Him about the parables.
verses.comment: Private explanation to the disciples reveals their privileged role; they receive deeper teaching as Jesus founds the community of faith.

verses.text: And He said to them, "To you has been given the mystery of the kingdom of God, but for those outside, all things are in parables,
verses.comment: The 'mystery' here refers to revealed divine truths given through divine authority to the apostles as the nucleus of the Church.

verses.text: so that 'they may indeed see but not perceive, and may indeed hear but not understand, lest they should turn and be forgiven.'"
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Isaiah, indicating God's judgment but also His desire for people to seek Him sincerely. Forgiveness is linked to conversion and entering God's people fully.

verses.text: And He said to them, "Do you not understand this parable? How then will you understand all the parables?"
verses.comment: Understanding the Word requires guidance and formation. The disciples are in a process of spiritual growth.

verses.text: "The sower sows the word."
verses.comment: Jesus interprets the parable—He is the Word incarnate, and also the sower. The center of the faith is Jesus Himself and His Word.

verses.text: These are the ones along the path, where the word is sown: when they hear, Satan immediately comes and takes away the word that is sown in them.
verses.comment: Spiritual enemies actively oppose the spread of Christ's teaching. The Church's spiritual combat and role in safeguarding the Word is highlighted here.

verses.text: And these are the ones sown on rocky ground: those who, when they hear the word, immediately receive it with joy.
verses.comment: Initial joy is not enough—endurance and formation are essential for lasting faith.

verses.text: But they have no root in themselves and endure only for a while; then, when tribulation or persecution arises on account of the word, immediately they fall away.
verses.comment: Perseverance is a mark of authentic faith. The theme of holding fast under persecution is stressed in New Testament letters (e.g., Hebrews).

verses.text: Others are the ones sown among thorns. They are those who hear the word,
verses.comment: Thorns represent competing desires and priorities, hindering a fruitful spiritual life.

verses.text: but the cares of the world, the deceitfulness of riches, and the desires for other things enter in and choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
verses.comment: Worldly distractions can overpower faith. Detachment from earthly goods and priorities is a necessary aspect of becoming fruitful.

verses.text: But those that were sown on the good soil are the ones who hear the word and accept it and bear fruit, thirtyfold and sixtyfold and a hundredfold."
verses.comment: Acceptance and obedience to God's Word leads to supernatural fruitfulness, alluding to union with Christ through both faith and good works.

verses.text: And He said to them, "Is a lamp brought in to be put under a basket, or under a bed, and not on a stand?"
verses.comment: Light symbolizes revealed truth and Jesus Himself (John 8:12). The Church is called to make His light visible to the world.

verses.text: For nothing is hidden except to be made manifest, nor is anything secret except to come to light.
verses.comment: In the divine plan, mysteries and secrets are revealed over time. Revelation is gradual and comes to fullness in Christ through His Church.

verses.text: If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear."
verses.comment: Repeated call to active listening, emphasizing the need to respond to Christ's teachings.

verses.text: And He said to them, "Pay attention to what you hear. With the measure you use, it will be measured to you, and still more will be added to you.
verses.comment: A principle of spiritual reciprocity. Generous hearts are rewarded by God. Echoes wisdom literature on God rewarding the faithful.

verses.text: For to the one who has, more will be given, and from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away."
verses.comment: Spiritual growth or loss depends on our openness to God's grace and truth. The principle applies individually but also corporately.

verses.text: And He said, "The kingdom of God is as if a man should scatter seed on the ground.
verses.comment: A new parable introduces the mysterious, organic growth of God's kingdom—by divine initiative and power.

verses.text: He sleeps and rises night and day, and the seed sprouts and grows; he does not know how.
verses.comment: God brings spiritual growth in ways beyond human understanding or merit. The process is both visible and hidden, pointing to grace at work in the Church.

verses.text: The earth produces by itself, first the blade, then the ear, then the full grain in the ear.
verses.comment: The stages of spiritual growth require patience and care—ultimately culminating in the fullness of the harvest at the end of the age.

verses.text: But when the grain is ripe, at once he puts in the sickle, because the harvest has come."
verses.comment: The harvest points prophetically to the final judgment and gathering of God's people at the end of the age.

verses.text: And He said, "With what can we compare the kingdom of God, or what parable shall we use for it?
verses.comment: Jesus compares the kingdom to illustrate its paradoxical and hidden beginnings, yet inevitable growth and triumph.

verses.text: It is like a grain of mustard seed, which, when sown on the ground, is the smallest of all the seeds on earth,
verses.comment: The mustard seed represents the humble origins of the kingdom, beginning with Christ and the apostles.

verses.text: yet when it is sown it grows up and becomes larger than all the garden plants and puts out large branches, so that the birds of the air can make nests in its shade."
verses.comment: The spread of God's kingdom will provide shelter for all nations (see Ezekiel 17, Daniel 4). The tree imagery evokes a worldwide, visible communion.

verses.text: With many such parables He spoke the word to them, as they were able to hear it.
verses.comment: Jesus adapts His teaching to the capacity of His audience, providing a model for catechesis and spiritual formation.

verses.text: He did not speak to them without a parable, but privately to His own disciples He explained everything.
verses.comment: Jesus entrusts the authoritative interpretation of His teaching to a specific group (the apostles), setting a foundation for handing on the faith.

verses.text: That day, when evening had come, He said to them, "Let us go across to the other side."
verses.comment: Jesus leads His disciples into new territory, symbolizing the mission to all peoples.

verses.text: And leaving the crowd, they took Him with them in the boat, just as He was. Other boats were with Him.
verses.comment: The narrative sets the stage for the coming miracle, highlighting both Jesus' humanity ('just as He was') and the presence of witnesses ('other boats').

verses.text: A great windstorm arose, and the waves were breaking into the boat, so that the boat was already filling.
verses.comment: The storm setting recalls Old Testament imagery of chaos and God's sovereignty over the sea (see Ps. 107).

verses.text: But He was in the stern, asleep on the cushion. And they woke Him and said to Him, "Teacher, do You not care that we are perishing?"
verses.comment: Jesus’ sleep underscores His true humanity. The disciples’ plea echoes prayers for divine help during crisis, foreshadowing intercessory prayer.

verses.text: And He awoke and rebuked the wind and said to the sea, "Peace! Be still!" And the wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
verses.comment: Jesus exercises divine authority over nature. In the Old Testament, only God commands the sea (Ps. 107:29). This displays Jesus' divinity.

verses.text: He said to them, "Why are you so afraid? Have you still no faith?"
verses.comment: Faith includes trust in Christ’s presence and power amid difficulties, pointing to the necessity of faith for miracles and salvation.

verses.text: And they were filled with great fear and said to one another, "Who then is this, that even the wind and the sea obey Him?"
verses.comment: The question underlines the high Christology of the text; Jesus’ authority over creation is a revelation of His divine identity—one with God, the Lord over chaos and nature.
